fields.descriptive_line: Dish, gilt metal inlaid with oxidised silver and set with silver medallions, Paris, 1855, made by Jules Wièse.
fields.materials_techniques: Gilt metal, inlaid with oxidised silver and set with silver medallions
fields.marks:
Marked WIESE PARIS twice (on inlay and rim)
Scratched inscription on back: Signature du Proprietaire de la Collection des Medailles - 1855
and : deliver a Mr Wiese
Medals signed A. Caque (1839 and 1840) and A. Bovy
 Foliage on tracery ground, medallions of Kings of France, from  Pharamond to  Louis - Philippe
Wreath of oak leaves
fields.public_access_description:
This dish is decorated with medals showing the kings of France. They begin with Pharamond and end in the centre with Louis-Philippe (ruled 1830–48). The dish was bought directly from the manufacturer for £40 in 1864. We do not know why it was made, or for whom, but its scale and subject suggest that it may have been conceived of as an exhibition piece, perhaps for the Paris Universal Exhibition of 1855. British journalists singled out Wièse for praise at that exhibition. The Post had this to say: ‘Jules Wièse is an artist of very exquisite taste. His Renaissance cups are perfection, and every object in his stall displays a thorough knowledge of middle-age art’. The Museum may have acquired the dish from him at this exhibition.

Wièse was trained in Berlin by the court goldsmith J. G. Hossauer. In 1839 he came to Paris to work for F. D. Froment-Meurice, one of the most eminent jewellers and goldsmiths. By 1844 he had set up on his own, although he still continued to work for Froment-Meurice. The Exhibition of 1855 was the first at which he exhibited in his own right. He won a Medal of Honour at the Universal Exhibition in London in 1862. His work was described as ‘of the highest merit, both in design and execution; principally of oxidised silver, and not costly, although admirable as examples of pure Art’.

The medals of the kings on the dish mainly date from 1839–40. Armand-Auguste Caqué's series of medals of the kings of France was well known, under the title Galerie numismatique des Rois de France. It was exhibited at the Paris Salons from 1836 to 1839. Bovy was a Swiss national who lived in Paris. He seems to have filled in the gaps in the series.
fields.history_note:
Bought from the manufacturer, M. Jules Wiese - £40.00. Possibly made for 1855 Paris Universal Exhibition
This dish, decorated with medals of kings of France from Pharamond to Louis-Philippe (in the centre), was bought directly from the manufacturer for £40 in 1864. It is not known for whom or why it was made, although its scale and subject suggest that it may have been conceived of as an exhibition piece, perhaps for the Paris Universal Exhibition of 1855. Wièse was singled out for praise by British journalists at that exhibition. The Post had this to say: "Jules Wièse is an artist of very exquisite taste. His Renaissance cups are perfection, and every object in his stall displays a thorough knowledge of middle-age art." It is not unlikely, therefore, that the Museum should have acquired the dish from him at this exhibition. Wièse was trained in Berlin by the court goldsmith J.G. Hossauer, but came to Paris in 1839 to work for F.D. Froment-Meurice, one of the most eminent jewellers and goldsmiths. By 1844 he had set up on his own, although continuing to work for Froment-Meurice, but the 1855 Exhibition was the first at which he exhibited in his own right. Wièse won medals at exhibitions in 1849, 1851 and 1855. His reputation was confirmed at the 1862 Universal Exhibition in London, where he won a Medal of Honour, his work being described as "of the highest merit, both in design and execution; principally of oxydised silver, and not costly, although admirable as examples of pure Art."

The medals of the kings on the dish mainly date from 1839-1840. Armand-Auguste Caqué's series of medals of the kings of France was well known, under the title "Galerie numismatique des Rois de France", and had been exhibited at the Paris Salons from 1836-1839. Bovy, a Swiss national who lived in Paris, seems to have filled the gaps in the series.
